node.title: What Was on the Best-Seller List 50 Years Ago?
node.description: Arthur Hailey and Joseph Last were in the top slots. Their subjects: cars and the Roosevelts.
node.content: ["SENTIMENTAL JOURNEY Now is the time of year when I feel a physical pang of nostalgia as I pull fingerpainted Christmas tree ornaments and a popsicle stick menorah out of a box labeled \u201cMaternity Clothes.\u201d (Don\u2019t ask.) Luckily I have a strong stomach for books of yore, so I took a walk down memory lane, to the best-seller list from Dec. 19, 1971. Here\u2019s what was all the rage 50 years ago.", "The No. 1 seller for fiction was \u201cWheels,\u201d by Arthur Hailey, which joined a series of blockbusters about industries the author researched for one year each. \u201cHotel\u201d (1965) was about the hospitality industry; \u201cAirport\u201d focused on aviation; and \u201cWheels,\u201d as our reviewer, John Reed, put it, \u201cis at once an expos\u00e9 and a salute to the auto industry.\u201d Reed, a freelance writer who \u201chas owned a Dodge, a Ford and a Buick,\u201d describes the novel as having a \u201cTolstoy-sized cast\u201d and \u201cmore windings than a Byzantine intrigue.\u201d However, he adds, \u201cMr. Hailey is nothing if not a competent craftsman; his directions are as easy to follow as an A.A.A. map.\u201d", "The No. 1 seller on the \u201cGeneral\u201d list (which included \u201cThe Last Whole Earth Catalog\u201d and \u201cAny Woman Can!,\u201d a guide to sexual fulfillment by David Reuben) was \u201cEleanor and Franklin,\u201d by Joseph Lash, which won the Pulitzer Prize. On Oct. 17, 1971, the 765-page volume was reviewed by Frank Freidel, a historian who was four volumes into his own six-volume biography of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Freidel credits Lash, a lifelong friend of Eleanor Roosevelt\u2019s, with bringing a fresh eye to her career. \u201cTo her opponents, Mrs. Roosevelt was the butt of innumerable jokes, a na\u00efve do-gooder, or even a dangerous radical,\u201d Freidel writes. \u201cTo her friends she was a beacon of hope and humanity, both during the Depression and in World War II, when she traveled even to the South Pacific to visit troops. She was the president\u2019s conscience, and in some ways that of the nation.\u201d", "In a letter dated Nov. 14, 1971, Earl and Dolores Schmidt of Slippery Rock, Pa., respond to Freidel\u2019s review. They write, \u201cHere at Slippery Rock State College, in a study of women in American history textbooks used for college survey courses, we chose one woman from each American century as the woman who should be included. Eleanor Roosevelt was our choice for the 20th century. Of 27 textbooks we examined, 15 did not mention her at all. One had a picture, but no textual references. Two mentioned only her name. Five devoted one sentence to her.\u201d"]
